channel.title: Comments on: How to script all stored procedures in a database
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Tabare
item.dc:creator: Tabare
item.content:encoded:
Hi guys,

I just wanted to say thanks; I’ve been looking for a way to replicate my system stored procedures before server migration, since master database backup is a pain in the…

Having to delete the return each 8K chars took me less than a minute, and your script saved me a lot of time and a headache.

Many, many thanks.

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.description: <a href="http://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/transactsql/thread/513b8547-9279-4bd1-b803-f11d02bb0f22">This thread</a> contains PowerShell script for scripting all stored procedures.
item.content:encoded: This thread contains PowerShell script for scripting all stored procedures.

item.description: The following site contains some simple sql to script out database objects: <a href="http://mangalpardeshi.blogspot.com/2009/03/script-all-store-procedures-in-database.html">http://mangalpardeshi.blogspot.com/2009/03/script-all-store-procedures-in-database.html</a>

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
May be. I’m just not proficient enough in it – don’t know how.

Here is an interesting link as how to do it with the PowerShell
Scripting Database Objects with PowerShell

item.title: By: Sandeep
item.dc:creator: Sandeep
item.description: Can't we use Powershell to achieve the same and quickly.?
item.content:encoded: Can’t we use Powershell to achieve the same and quickly.?

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
Yes, the print command only can show 8K characters, that’s why we used looping in the code to get 8000 characters to print then next 8000.

Adam’s bcp trick seems to be the simplest way of getting all procedure codes into a file.

item.title: By: niikola
item.dc:creator: niikola
item.content:encoded:
If the procedure size is longer than 8K result of PRINT will be truncated in Management Studio, regardless of any settings I could find, even if you are using varchar(max).

If you execute it via sqlcmd you get everything and you don’t need Print @var(Left,8000).

It seems print command can print only 8k strings inside studio while it works fine in sqlcmd.
